M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28**, granting the Probate and Family Court continuing authority to modify custody orders when the welfare of the child so requires.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: ### **COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION OF CUSTODY ORDER**  (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; M.G.L. c. 215, § 6)

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers under **M.G.L. c. 215, § 6** to enter such orders as justice and equity may require to safeguard a child’s welfare.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Since entry of the May 10, 2021 order, circumstances have materially changed within the meaning of **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28** and relevant caselaw, including but not limited to *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: Yannas addresses the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30 (the ‘real advantage’ test), not modification of custody or parenting-time orders for ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The opinion contains no discussion of § 28 or of what constitutes a material change in circumstances after a prior order. Citing Yannas as authority for a § 28 ‘material change’ proposition misattributes its holding, even though later cases sometimes integrate Yannas’ removal analysis once a modification is otherwise properly before the court.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Since entry of the May 10, 2021 order, circumstances have materially changed within the meaning of **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28** and relevant caselaw, including but not limited to *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: Custody of Kali is a nonmarital custody case under G.L. c. 209C, not a divorce or post‑divorce modification case under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The opinion expressly declines to apply or discuss the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modification, focusing instead on initial custody determinations and the ‘best interests of the child’ under c. 209C, § 10. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that circumstances have ‘materially changed’ within the meaning of c. 208, § 28, even though it is relevant to best‑interests analysis generally.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Since entry of the May 10, 2021 order, circumstances have materially changed within the meaning of **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28** and relevant caselaw, including but not limited to *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that a relocation/removal event constitutes a material change of circumstances within the meaning of M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related caselaw. Mason does not cite § 28 directly, but it expressly adopts the ALI Principles § 2.17(1), which states that a parent’s relocation "constitutes a substantial change in circumstances" when it significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise custodial responsibilities. The SJC quotes and endorses that standard in a removal context under c. 208, § 30, thereby supporting the notion that relocation/removal can amount to the kind of material change that justifies modification proceedings under Massachusetts custody statutes, including § 28.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce].’ … ALI Principles … support[] the view that where ‘neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility,’ the effect of the relocation on the child is a ‘relevant factor[]’ in determining the child’s best interests.”}

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The environment described poses a **risk to the welfare and development of the child**, satisfying the “changed circumstances” requirement set out in *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000); and *Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Mass. 28 (2003).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The proposition invokes Custody of Vaughn as authority on a ‘changed circumstances’ requirement tied to an environment posing risk to a child’s welfare and development. Custody of Vaughn is not a modification case and does not articulate or apply any ‘changed circumstances’ standard; instead, it concerns an initial custody determination and imposes a requirement that probate judges make explicit findings about the impact of domestic violence on the child when awarding custody. While the opinion recognizes that exposure to domestic violence is profoundly harmful to children, it does not frame that harm in terms of satisfying a changed-circumstances threshold for modifying an existing order.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).proposition: The environment described poses a **risk to the welfare and development of the child**, satisfying the “changed circumstances” requirement set out in *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000); and *Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Mass. 28 (2003).
*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).support_reasoning: The excerpt from Adoption of Vito focuses on parental unfitness, the child’s strong bond with the foster/adoptive family, and whether postadoption contact with the biological mother is in the child’s best interests. It does not discuss or apply a ‘changed circumstances’ requirement of the type referenced in Custody of Vaughn or Care & Protection of Georgette, nor does it frame the child’s environment as a ‘changed circumstance’ for modification purposes. Thus, while the case addresses best interests and risk of harm conceptually, it does not support the specific proposition about satisfying a ‘changed circumstances’ requirement.
*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “Where, as here, the child has formed strong, nurturing bonds with his preadoptive family, and there is little or no evidence of a significant, existing bond with the biological parent, judicial exercise of equitable power to require postadoption contact would usually be unwarranted. On the other hand, a judicial order for postadoption contact may be warranted where the evidence readily points to significant, existing bonds between the child and a biological parent, such that a court order abruptly disrupting that relationship would run counter to the child’s best interests.”

*Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Ma.proposition: The environment described poses a **risk to the welfare and development of the child**, satisfying the “changed circumstances” requirement set out in *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550 (2000); and *Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Mass. 28 (2003).
*Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Ma.support_reasoning: This opinion is focused on ineffective assistance/conflict of interest standards for children’s counsel, not on the ‘changed circumstances’ requirement or on evaluating whether a new environment poses risk to the child’s welfare as a basis to revisit custody. While it notes that there was ‘overwhelming proof of the father’s unfitness’ and ‘risk of harm’ if the girls were returned, those statements are background and not tied to any analysis of changed circumstances under Custody of Vaughn or Adoption of Vito. The case therefore does not serve as authority for the specific proposition about satisfying a changed‑circumstances requirement.
*Care & Protection of Georgette*, 439 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “There is no question that the children are entitled to counsel, that their autonomy and rights to be heard on issues affecting their interest should be respected, and that their positions, based on mature expression, are entitled to weight in custody proceedings (although not determinative). … [C]ounsel represents siblings … and faces a care and protection or termination of parental rights case … that presents compelling evidence demonstrating parental unfitness and the likely risk of harm to the children if returned to the unfit parent….”

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: See *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981) (holding a material change in circumstances warrants modification of custody or support orders); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) (modification appropriate when substantial changes affect the child’s best interests).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that to succeed on a complaint to modify alimony or child support, the moving party must show a “material change of circumstances” since the earlier judgment, and it applies that standard in affirming the denial of modification. Although the case focuses on alimony and support rather than custody, it clearly establishes the material-change standard for modification of support orders, which is the part of the proposition for which it is cited.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: See *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981) (holding a material change in circumstances warrants modification of custody or support orders); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) (modification appropriate when substantial changes affect the child’s best interests).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly states that a modification of custody must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances and that such a change must make modification necessary in the child’s best interests, but it does *not* say that any substantial change that affects the child’s best interests makes modification appropriate. In fact, the court reverses a modification because no qualifying material and substantial change was shown, emphasizing that relocation and a court‑imposed temporary change in custody alone are insufficient. Thus the case refines and limits, rather than broadly supporting, the claimed proposition.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The guiding principle under Massachusetts law remains the **best interests of the child**, a standard articulated in *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981), *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976), and reaffirmed in *Custody of Kali*, supra.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in custody determinations, the “overriding concern” of the court must be promotion of the best interests and general welfare of the children, and it applies that standard in reviewing the custody award. It also cites earlier Massachusetts cases, including Vilakazi v. Maxie, as recent restatements of this best-interests principle. Thus, Rolde directly affirms that the guiding standard under Massachusetts law in custody matters is the best interests of the child.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… For a recent restatement of these principles, see Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1976). … The ‘best interests’ principle requires that the narrow focus be on the interests of the child.”

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: The guiding principle under Massachusetts law remains the **best interests of the child**, a standard articulated in *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981), *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976), and reaffirmed in *Custody of Kali*, supra.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody matters the “governing principle” is the welfare of the child and describes this as the “dominating rule,” reaffirming earlier Massachusetts precedents. That language is essentially equivalent to the “best interests of the child” standard and confirms that child welfare is the controlling consideration in custody determinations. Thus, Vilakazi v. Maxie squarely supports the proposition that the best interests/welfare of the child is the guiding principle under Massachusetts law.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939)….”
